title: 109_hr2491
content: The Act titled "International Solid Waste Importation and Management Act of 2006" adds a new section to the Solid Waste Disposal Act regarding the international transportation and disposal of municipal solid waste. The Act "International Solid Waste Importation and Management Act of 2006" allows states to regulate the importation and disposal of foreign municipal solid waste until all final regulations of the Agreement are in effect. State actions authorized by this section should not unduly burden interstate or foreign commerce. The Act allows states to regulate the importation and disposal of foreign municipal solid waste without unduly burdening interstate or foreign commerce. The Administrator is authorized to perform functions under the Agreement and enforce its provisions. The Administrator must issue final regulations within 24 months of enactment regarding their responsibilities. When considering importation consent under the Agreement, the Administrator must give weight to state and local government views and assess the impact on recycling programs. The importation of municipal solid waste must adhere to State and local recycling programs, consider landfill capacity, air emissions, and road deterioration from increased vehicular traffic. Violations of the agreement are prohibited, and compliance orders may be issued by the Administrator. The Administrator may issue civil penalties or commence civil actions for violations of waste importation regulations. Penalties can reach $25,000 per day of noncompliance, considering the seriousness of the violation and efforts to comply. The Administrator can issue civil penalties up to $25,000 per day for noncompliance with compliance orders. If corrective action is not taken within the specified time, a public hearing can be requested within 30 days of the order being served. The Administrator has the authority to issue subpoenas and establish rules for discovery procedures. The term 'Agreement' refers to the Agreement Concerning the Transboundary Movement of Hazardous Waste between the US and Canada, along with regulations and orders to enforce it. 'Foreign municipal solid waste' is waste generated outside the US. 'Municipal solid waste' includes all waste materials discarded by households for disposal. The curr_chunk discusses waste disposal by households, hotels, and commercial sources, emphasizing materials collected and disposed of with municipal solid waste as part of normal collection services. The curr_chunk discusses municipal solid waste, which includes various materials like food waste, paper, clothing, and household hazardous waste. It also covers debris from construction, remodeling, and demolition of structures. The curr_chunk defines municipal solid waste and excludes hazardous waste and contaminated soil resulting from response actions under environmental laws. The curr_chunk discusses recyclable materials separated from waste, scrap rubber as a fuel source, and materials returned for credit. The curr_chunk discusses solid waste generated by an industrial facility and transported for treatment, storage, or disposal to a facility owned by the generator or its affiliate. The curr_chunk outlines specific types of waste that can be disposed of in compliance with local and State regulations, including medical waste, sewage sludge, combustion ash from resource recovery facilities, and manufacturing waste not typically generated by households. The curr_chunk discusses solid waste generated incident to air transportation services, amending the Table of Contents of the Solid Waste Disposal Act. The curr_chunk discusses international transportation and disposal of municipal solid waste, passed by the House of Representatives on September 6, 2006.
